trial_identification.studytitle: Modulation of systemic reaction to operation in liver surgery: A prospective randomised study on the Impact of preoperative steroids administration on systemic responses to liver surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Impact of preoperative steroids administration on surgical stress in patients undergoing liver surgery

conditions.healthcondition: Patients undergoing liver surgery for benign and malignant disease

interventions.interventions: Single Intravenous Administration of 500 mg of methylprednisolone at the induction of anaesthesia. Several markers of surgical stress, liver function and coagulation were evaluated for 5 days after the surgical procedure. Postoperative complication were evaluated until post operative day 30.
interventions.comparator: Control: Saline solution - used instead of methylprednisolone.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Serum levels of tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF) and interleukin 6 (IL-6), as indicators of the surgical stress response, were measured at the induction of anaesthesia and on post operative day (POD) 1, 2 and 5. Serum levels were quantified by using an enzyme linked immunosorbent assay kit according to the manufacturer's specifications (Bouty, Milan, Italy). Samples were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 minutes and stored at 80 degrees Celsius until analysis. Data were then presented as picograms per millilitre. The detection limit of the assay was 1 pg/mL for TNF- and 0.1 pg/mL for IL-6. Postoperative complications

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Liver function : Bilirubin Hepatic ischemia reperfusion : alanine aminotransferase (ALT) Coagulation homeostasis : antithrombin III (AT-III), prothrombin time-international normalized ratio, fibrinogen, D dimer, and platelets

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients undergoing liver surgery for benign and malignant disease
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: -Concomitant extrahepatic surgery -Intraoperative radiofrequency -Suspected active infective disease

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomisation table created by a computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Preoperative steroid administration may represent a safe and effective modulator of surgical stress, may reduce hepatic ischemia reperfusion injury, maintain coagulant/anticoagulant homeostasis, and reduce postoperative complication by modulating the inflammatory response.
